repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Make `vim.iter():take()` and `vim.iter():skip()`
optionally accept predicates to enable takewhile
and skipwhile patterns used in functional
programming. #33202

<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

comment_data.body:
This is not quite right because `next()` can return multiple values. So you could pack it into a table first, and then unpack it. But this is pretty bad for performance. You'll note that the implementations of `filter()` and `map()` have a similar problem and they go to great contortions to address it.

Also we shouldn't pass the index to the function, we don't do that for any other method. If the user wants the index they can call `enumerate()` first which includes the index as one of the iterator values. Staying consistent makes everything more composable.

Simple (but possibly slow) implementation:

```suggestion
    local val = pack(next(self))
    if f(unpack(val)) then
      return unpack(val)
```

For a solution that avoids the `pack` and `unpack` dance you can look at what `map()` does.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -693,24 +694,54 @@ end
 --- -- 2
 --- it:next()
 --- -- nil
+---
+--- local function pred(x) return x < 2 end
+--- local it2 = vim.iter({ 1, 2, 3, 4 }):take(pred)
+--- it2:next()
+--- -- 1
+--- it2:next()
+--- -- nil
 --- ```
 ---
----@param n integer
+---@generic A
+---
+---@param f integer|fun(a:A, i:integer):boolean Either the number if values to
+---                                             take or a predicate which takes
+---                                             a value and it's index.
 ---@return Iter
-function Iter:take(n)
+function Iter:take(f)
+  if type(f) ~= 'function' then
+    local n = f
+    f = function(_, i)
+      return i <= n
+    end
+  end
+
   local next = self.next
-  local i = 0
+  local i = 1
   self.next = function()
-    if i < n then
+    local val = next(self)
+    if f(val, i) then
       i = i + 1
-      return next(self)
+      return val

comment_data.body: Thanks for the feedback, I tried a solution without the packing/unpacking similar to `map()` .

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    Skips `n` values of an iterator pipeline, or all values satisfying a
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4518,17 +4518,24 @@ Iter:rskip({n})                                                 *Iter:rskip()*
         (`Iter`)
 
 Iter:skip({n})                                                   *Iter:skip()*
-    Skips `n` values of an iterator pipeline.
+    Skips `n` values of an iterator pipeline, or the first values satisfying a

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    Transforms an iterator to yield only the first n values, or all
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4546,7 +4553,8 @@ Iter:slice({first}, {last})                                     *Iter:slice()*
         (`Iter`)
 
 Iter:take({n})                                                   *Iter:take()*
-    Transforms an iterator to yield only the first n values.
+    Transforms an iterator to yield only the first n values, or the first

comment_data.body: Does it simplify the code if the "number" case is implemented by setting `n` to a predicate? Same for skip().
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -693,11 +694,35 @@ end
 --- -- 2
 --- it:next()
 --- -- nil
+---
+--- local function pred(x) return x < 2 end
+--- local it2 = vim.iter({ 1, 2, 3, 4 }):take(pred)
+--- it2:next()
+--- -- 1
+--- it2:next()
+--- -- nil
 --- ```
 ---
----@param n integer
+---@param n integer|fun(...):boolean Number of values to take or a predicate.
 ---@return Iter
 function Iter:take(n)
+  if type(n) == 'function' then

comment_data.body: it looks like the number case is supported (below), so why can't the predicate case be supported?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -782,11 +819,19 @@ end
 --- it:next()
 --- -- 9
 ---
+--- local function pred(x) return x < 10 end
+--- local it2 = vim.iter({ 3, 6, 9, 12 }):skip(pred)
+--- it2:next()
+--- -- 12
 --- ```
 ---
----@param n number Number of values to skip.
+---@param n integer|fun(...):boolean Number of values to skip or a predicate.
 ---@return Iter
 function Iter:skip(n)
+  if type(n) == 'function' then
+    error('skip() with predicate requires an array-like table')

comment_data.body:
We would need to evaluate the predicate with the next element, but we shouldn't advance the iterator if the predicate doesn't hold. Peek isn't implemented for dict-like tables:
```lua
function Iter:peek()
  error('peek() requires an array-like table')
end
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:

+--- it2:next()

 --- ```

----@param n number Number of values to skip.

 ---@return Iter
 function Iter:skip(n)
+  if type(n) == 'function' then
+    error('skip() with predicate requires an array-like table')

comment_data.body:
I cooked something up with
```lua
  local i = 0
  local f = n
  if type(n) ~= 'function' then
    f = function()
      return i < n
    end
  end
```
and the code is a bit shorter.

For the array iterator skip and take, I think the logic should stay separate because in the number case it can be done in O(1) time, but O(n) for the predicate case.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body: These tests look good for testing the behavior on arrays. Can you also add some tests to cover the behavior for non-arrays (function iterators and other tables)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -159,6 +159,38 @@ describe('vim.iter', function()
       eq({}, vim.iter(q):skip(#q + 1):totable())
     end
 
+    do

comment_data.body: These are good -- can you do these for `skip` too?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -271,6 +319,24 @@ describe('vim.iter', function()
       -- non-array iterators are consumed by take()
       eq({}, it:take(2):totable())
     end
+
+    do
+      eq({ 'a', 'b', 'c', 'd' }, vim.iter(vim.gsplit('a|b|c|d', '|')):take(correct):totable())
+      eq(
+        { 'a', 'b', 'c' },
+        vim
+          .iter(vim.gsplit('a|b|c|d', '|'))
+          :enumerate()
+          :take(function(i, x)
+            return i < 3 or x == 'c'
+          end)
+          :map(function(_, x)
+            return x
+          end)
+          :totable()
+      )
+      eq({}, vim.iter(vim.gsplit('a|b|c|d', '|')):take(wrong):totable())

comment_data.body: I made skip on non array-like tables raise an error, there's an explanation above.

title: feat(runtime): accept predicates in take and skip
